text: Bootloop on the G5 is not as common like the G4, but there are another issues with this phone like the screen ghost on the LCD, GPS losing signal, the autofocus on the camera stop working and lower quality build like the battery holder lock failing off.

Build quality questionable. Audio jack stopped working after 16 months. The lock for battery holder became loose after about 18 months (it means you are loosing the microphone unexpectedly during conversation). The additional attachment: camera controler with an additional battery stopped working after 1 yr. Otherwise, the unit is/was performing well.
Lg G5 is one of the best smartphones which is forgotten, the only drawback is battery, otherwise it is still a beast.

Best phone i have ever owned my first phone was a flip phone then i went to a iPhone 4 huge upgrade btw. Then i started getting into technology alot and realized the iPhone can only be as smart as they make it so i jumed ship to android and it was some cheap plastic screen phone but it was as quick as my 4 and did way more then i upgraded to the lg g2 and fell in love with the design. Eventually i got the g4 buyer beware it blows. But then i got the g5 as a last attempt from lg and it blew me away the finger print scanner is in the best spot ever my finger always hits it even when i don't mean to. I dont like how they moved the volume buttons to the side i think for listening to music it made it easier to change volumes if the phone was in your pocket. Moving on the camera is great but nothing to write home about.. The screen is great again not the best but you arent spending a huge amount of money on the phone (i paid about $250 at amazon) the back camera glass is very fragile atleast for me before i got a good case i cracked the glass twice. Somewhat easy diy fix. The thing that makes the phone shine isnt the mods but the removable battery i cant tell you how valuable this is even if you don't battery swap so your phone instantly has 100% plus you can get a new battery when yours gets to old and if your charger port or speakers break or get stuff in them $20 later you have a brand new bottom clip/speakers/charger port. Again buyer beware some clips may or may not work i believe it depends on your model #. Overall i think this android phone beats every iPhone made and 99% of Android phones out there and for the price you'd almost be ignorant to at least try it.

The G5 has one MASSIVE flaw that makes every other feature on this phone moot in my opinion.   It is nearly impossible to answer incoming calls!  When the phone displays an incoming call, pressing, pressing and holding, swiping, whatever, has no effect and it's a hit or miss if you'll be able to get the phone to pick up before it goes to voicemail.  This is a HUGE flaw by LG andan unforgivable one regardless of any other features this phone has. I have seen this unable to answer phone issue on 3 separate G5's so I know it wasn't just my particular device.

Great phone but definitely get a proper case if worries about getting wet. All cameras are amazing but night time video is not so great. 
 
Biggest two problems for me: lightbleed and image retention. When watching videos with black bars I could definitely see light leaking in from 2 corners. Image retention solved with night filter app but from minimal filter but over time  I had to increase to the point where screen is too dim and too red. Is okay for me for normal use but when I watch video and increase brightness red tint is too noticeable. 
 
Great phone if you do not have problems with screen. But I highly recommend having at least 2 batteries. I probably connected to charger less than 10 times in 14minths with phone. There is nothing more satisfying that having a fully charged battery in less than a minute when you have to run out the door. 
 
Good luck!

This phone has major issues with its power and its connectivity - both fundamental features. The phone repeatedly shuts itself down before the power is anywhere near depleted. LG's solution: Pay them $150 to look at the phone. So disabuse yourself of any thought that LG Canada offers good customer care and do yourself a favour and DO NOT BUY THIS PHONE. I got mine July of 2016 and its still going however I had to do 2 hardware repairs, one for the charge port (stopped working and couldn't boot phone), one for the power button (stopped registering), and one mod for the GPS. All LG G series phones I have seen have an issue with GPS. I repair phones for a job so stuff like that is nothing to fix. However this phone apart from those issues is extremely fast still and love it. Its why I fixed the issues, I have 3 phones but my G5 is still my go to phone and one of them is the new Samsung A5

There is a way to fix that I have done it, I still use my G5 and have had it for over a year now. I had to fix it recently because it broke down but when it was down I didn't realise how good or fast it was until I had to use my iPhone 6 lol however it does have issues still that have been there since day one, like GPS (fixed), Screen Burn-in issues, over heating, and power button wouldn't register (fixed). I'm a cell phone tech so its easy to fix issues like these. The GPS is a simple fix, it involves you taking your phone apart though, there is a video on YouTube on how to do it. Its just 3 pins on the motherboard that need to be lifted to connect with the flex connectors that are attached to the frame. Look up a video to do it, use that video at your own risk though and it does void warranty.

I like the LG G5, but only when the following are set up and applied to the device. Update to the latest Nougat update. Install app "Blue Light Filter - Night Mode," then set the color temperature to 1800k and the intensity to 5%. (This solves the screen retention issues) I went an extra step and put copper heat strips on the emmc, cpu, and gpu. (This may be unessisary) Buy a battery charging case so you have an extra battery. Disable knockOn with an app that can access all your settings. Get an app named "SystemUI Tuner" adb all the commands to the phone and then change your screen animations to 0.4 setting, and change all the quick notifications to show 7 of them above when you pull the notification jore down. Also enable developer options and enable "Forced GPU Rendering." Forced GPU Rendering disabled is the main culprit for the phone preforming slowly while you are using it. (You will have to do your own research on these to change them/fix them) Coarse get another home launcher..I recommend Nova Launcher Prime. Now you are set!
 
Extra stuff I did to my LG G5.
 
I got Tasker and did some automation to make the phone more useful (not nessisary, but I enjoy it)
 
I installed an app named "Tiles." It allows you to have many custom quick notifications options.
 
I also use Open Camera with manual exposure when taking photos.
 
Hope some of this helps!

You need to get the app named "Blue Light Filter - Night Mode." Once you get the blue light filter app set the color temp to 1800k then set the intensity to 5%. Once you do this the ghosting you are calling it will disappear. It isn't ghosting btw, it is screen retention. Ghosting is way worse than screen retention. When screen retention occurs if disappears about 5 minutes later when the display is off.

After 9 months? You got lucky. My G5 got image retention after just 4 months. And I just noticed last night under Nova Settings in night mode which shows a dark grayish background that my V20 at nearly 4 months is also starting to show it! Bootloop was a problem in LG's 2015 flagships. Cheap displays with ghosting was their problem in 2016.
 
I still love my V20 though. I forget it was military-graded for drops and that's why zero flaws when it fell face first to the tile. Even the paint didn't scrape off. My Moto E has been dropped and shows nothing too. My Lumia 640 dropped and shows nothing. Motorola and Nokia build strong phones. My Pixel was dropped inside its holster case. Flawless. My G3 Beat shows cracks on the top after it fell from the bed. G5 shows a dent after one waist high fall INSIDE its holster case. SMH. 
 
LG has used cheap plastic or glass that easily dents throughout their G-series going back to Optimus G. Only G2 seemed well-built and it lacked microSD slot, removable battery, and was glossy plastic. G3, G4, G5 aren't  built to withstand drops. G6 is glass. It was only until the V-series is when LG started to care about durability with its military-graded materials but it looks like the V30 will follow the footsteps of the G6.  
 
Like I said before, I will always stick to Android but I have been dual wielding both it and iOS as of late. I love the size and design of the iPhone SE. Still more SExy than the iPhone 7 and 8 series. I sometimes forget how smooth iOS can be. I just hate its restrictions. So Pixel on Verizon is the one I plan to stay on unless Nokia 8 or Essential Phone can convince me otherwise. 
 
Stay away from LG unless it the materials are military-graded to withstand drops. Like the Samsung S series, LG G series are built CHEAP. Motorola and Nokia are better engineers for durability and reliability. Apple, HTC, and Sony are definitely higher than Samsung, LG, and most of the Chinese. Will still keep my V20 because it will be the last flagship to offer removable battery.

I swear, I think I wasn't meant to own the G5. A couple days ago, it accidentally fell waist high. It was still inside the holster case. Just recently, I noticed a slight dent on the top of the phone. It is annoying to look at.  In comparison, my V20 was dragged to the tile because I forgot to detach it from the laptop. It falls facedown. No holster case. No damage whatsoever. Not even a scratch. I was surprised thinking the damage might show a day later or so. 
 
I'm planning to sell the G5 now. It feels like it was made out of tin can. First the ghosting. Then battery drain after update which was remedied by restore to new. Now its fragility. Both it and the S7 edge will be put on sale. I plan to use only the Pixel (Verizon), V20 (media), and iPhone SE (GPS). I have some bad luck with the G5. My V20 on the other hand isn't perfect by any means. But reliable and better in most important aspects, it is. 
 
Pixel. V20. SE.

So I deleted it as well as Dasher, LG backup, restore to new, restore from backup, and everything is back to normal. Took less than 1 hr to get everything back to once it was with just tweaking with the Settings app. The battery calibration is probably out of sync once we update to every major firmware.

Be prepared for image retention. Many user report this issue. Happened to my G5 after about 8 months. Solved with an app called Blue Light Filter.

 G5 and should be fine. Or get a lifeproof case :D

And I'm still on marshmallow. Too many reports of problems on Nougat. I still get 4hrs screen time, 15hrs use from original battery and 4.5-5hrs and 18hrs use on second battery. 50% bright ness.
 
It has a curved screen at top so tempered screen protectors don't fully protect. The ones that do curve aren't sticky at the top so dust gets in. I dont use protector anymore and I dont have any scratches.
 
Its a slippery phone and I've dropped it so on sides I have some scuffs. But its pretty tough.
 
Headphones don't sound as good as G6 or V20 but speaker is loud.
 
But I still love my G5 and didn't upgrade to G6 because:
 
-Battery life is same and can change anytime. In the last 6months I've only ever been connected to a charger a few times. And when battery degrades I just get a new one.  
 
-G5 has same size storage, led notifier, IR blaster, and better selfie cam. 
 
-Not enough for me to upgrade. Yes, G6 better with water resistant, screen size vs body size, wireless charging, wide angle better and its prettier. But after using my friends for a bit, I don't think it was worth spending on the next model. Don't get me wrong, G6 is a great phone but the G5 is still fast enough for me. I'd rather wait for the bigger OLED LG V30 or th LG made Pixel2 (with front facing speaker?)

V20 has the perfect battery swap tech. It has removable back. That is why you can replace the stock battery to a bigger, higher capacity extended battery like ZeroLemon or Mugen extended battery. It is the main reason why V20 is better than G5. G5 does not have removable back so it's not possible to make extended battery for G5, that's why you can't find any.
 
Moreover, in a post-apocalypse situation if your phone has removable battery and removable back cover, you can mod it to work with 18650 batteries. 18650 batteries are standard, more widely available, so there is a good chance that you will find them in the local shops.
Modular design is huge advantage over V20. It's cool how we can swap batteries on g5, I dont really like v20 because of outdated battery swap tech

How long do you want to use this phone, and what do you want to do with it? 
The S7 is unquestionably prettier and more pleasant to use in full sunlight. 
The G5 is more versatile for power users because of the USB Type C port and the alt modes LG packed in there to support all those friends that never happened. But hey! seriously, you can use a bunch of different adapters or cables to connect this little beast directly to tvs, monitors, external hard drives (watch the FAT16 limitation of Android), mouse and keyboard--the list seems to go on and on. On top of that, you have options from the earphone jack, bluetooth, DLNA, wireless streaming, and an IR blaster. I have an unlimited data plan through my mobile carrier and stream HD to my tv- for that, I think a cable is better. My phone is in constant use, with the screen on. I have 6 batteries and 2 charging cradles. It's plenty safe to carry an extra battery around in a plastic baggy. LGs testing includes shooting nails through batteries to make sure they won't explode. There are videos online of drop and water tests. If it should break, its the easiest phone ever to take apart and fix. Both phones are now half or less of their original retail price.

Pros: 
- Butter smooth performance. 
- Love the wide-angle camera, especially if you're taking a lot of Scenery photos. 
- One of the few last flagship phones that you can remove / replace your battery.
 
Cons ( ... and these are big ones): 
- Due to the LG G5 using an LCD screen, it's prone to screen burn in. I can still see the google keyboard icon on darker backgrounds, even though I removed that months ago. 
- The GPS sucks. It takes at least 5 - 10 minutes to get a GPS signal, and at that point it's erratic and unreliable. This is a VERY big con. 
- Terrible after sales support. I've tried to contact LG, but keep getting referred back to my Network Provider.
 
I'm very sorry to say that I will not be buying another LG Phone. I tried to move away from Samsung due to their terrible re-skinned UI and immense bloatware, but at least the hardware was fantastic.

After a few days of toying around with the G5 I gotta say that it's a nice phone. I got the AT&T unlocked version from EBAY for around 165 bucks so I didn't pay very much for it and I'm now getting free phone service from FREEDOMPOP. That being said it's a good deal for the price. The SD820 chipset is a little outdated right now with the SD821 and SD835 coming out but it's still a monster for average users. I'm crazy into mobile games so processing power and graphics are very important, and the G5 certainly doesn't disappoint though it's nowhere near the fastest- but then again I paid 165 for it who gives a shit. 
 
Thing is the V20 is a lot better. It has better audio and video features and the performance is better, though it uses the same chipset. But you're paying $299 for a scum-of-the-earth used variant from EBAY while the G5 pushes $150 in it's lowest configurations. If you're like me and you don't give much of a shit of anything besides PRICE and PERFORMANCE the G5 is a solid bargain. If you want the best of LG you're getting the V20, and if you want the absolute best but don't give a shit about your burdened wallet then the G6 is the way to go. Personally I had to choose long and hard before choosing the G5 over the S7...
 
Another thing before buying this phone. The bloat is INSANE. I got the AT&T version and it's actually hard to determine which apps are legit and which are not. I hate the fact that you can't uninstall ANY OF IT! Worst part is there's no root for LG G5 available yet- One-click root doesn't work either because the bootloader is locked. The EU and T-MOBILE versions are the only root-compatible ones but I'm pretty darn disappointed I can't root my phone so I can get rid of all that useless crap that AT&T dragged from the deepest pits of hell. If you're into modding or toying around the OS then stay WELL AWAY.
 
VERDICT: Buy it if you're on a serious budget. If you have money to burn then stay away.

Pros: Performance, camera
 
Cons: Build quality, screen leaking, fragile screen, back button 
 
I bought my LG G5 after owning a LG G3 which I wasn't satisified with (LG service center replaced my motherboard and battery 3 times in 3 years for free ). I gave LG another shot because everyone was saying that their new G5 is the best android phone available at that moment. 
 
First day I used it the performance was great, it looked cool, although I was a bit suspicious of it's build quality. The third day my back button just stopped working out of nowhere so I had to use double click on the screen to unlock / lock my phone. A week later my mobile phone fell from my pocket to a hardwood floor and the screen broke. I paid for the new screen and they fixed my back button with no questions asked for free so I think it's a problem they often have. After I repaired the phone I dropped it again after 3 days and the screen broke in the exact same place. I mean, I know your phone isn't supposed to hit the floor, but if the screen breaks every time the mobile phone hits something and in the exact same place, that's a matter of build quality and it's silly to sell a high end mobile phone with such a fragile screen.
 
Now I'm on my way to return the phone and I will never buy any electronic device from LG again because I gave them a chance and they disappointed me.

Pros: Performance is great, camera is great, display is great, battery is removable, fast charging is incredible.
 
Cons: Battery life is poor, build quality is poor, ghost screen problem still exists, no equalizer in 2017 (LG pls..), bottom of the phone doesn't fit very well, speakers aren't loud enough.

Last night, the V20 initially lagged during setup and got hot. Probably has to do with all the bloated T-Mobile apps downloading. Happened to my S7 edge setup too. Probably a TMo thing. This did NOT happened to my G5 or Pixel though. 
 
I noticed the micro-lag early on when browsing. Then I did the typical 0.5x animations, turned off auto update in Google Play settings and auto sync, rid of Facebook, installed SwiftKey, and everything is pretty smooth now. I do believe the G5 is more sensitive to my touch. Will install Nova Prime later and see how it goes. 
 
I really didn't think I would like the huge screen but ever since I got my Note 3 has a hand me down just six months ago, I got used to these "surfboard" phones pretty quickly. Typing on my 5" phones like the Pixel feels kinda cramped now. 
 
Hopefully, the V20 will be a pretty great phone like the G5 and Pixel are. Those two seem a tad smoother than it so far. I could return it in two weeks for a refund but there is a $50 restocking fee. I already like typing on it far more than the annoying S7 edge curved display. 
 
I don't like where LG is headed this year and going for sealed battery on flagships. V30 might go sealed. Removable battery, ftw!  G5 and V20 could be the last of their breed among flagships. Both underrated af too.

My issues so far from end of Sept '16:
 
-lightbleed on 2 corners noticeable when watching video in dim lit room. I think it got worse because now I see a bit on the edges in dark. Unfixable. That is horrible for a flagship and my biggest complaint.
 
- screen ghosting. Annoying after image of notification bar or YouTube video seen in dark areas of image on screen. Easy fix by using a blue light filter. Annoying to use a 3rd party app but meh. Fixable.
 
- when playing game RP watching video 100% heats up but never to point of crash or cannot hold b/c of heat. Max bright 75% and no problems. Unfixable but Meh. To be expected.
 
- when using quick charge heats up from 2% to 20% then cools off. Meh. To be expected. But fixable by using swappable battery or Normal charger, no heat.
 
- battery clip-in not as tight as when first got it. Meh. I change battery quite often so probably worn down.  Battery has not fallen out and okay fine b/c the most useful modular design of this phone: that the bottom piece is cheap to replace. Problem with speaker, charging port, mic or battery clip? Problem with all above? $20 all in one replacement part. Cheap and fast. Good work LG.
 
-spilt beer on power button and had to replace. My fault but no issues with button since. Fixable. But reason I want water resistant phone again. My Moto g4plus took a dive into a puddle and never had a prob in 6months usage with it.
 
-headphones not as loud nor rich as my old g4. Unfixable but Meh its okay b/c I use Bluetooth headphones.
 
Other than lightbleed, still love my G5. ;D

One of the most underrated, underappreciated, and misunderstood smartphones of all-time. This is a phone that deserves a cult following as time goes by... 
 
Critics can bash the design but the Google Pixel is far uglier. The matte iPhone 7 is now dealing with Scuffgate Part 2. The G5's build quality isn't prone to smudges or shatter either like the S7 edge or any phone with a glass rear will have. Has LCD which last longer than OLED and less potential burn-in. 
 
This is one of the most perfect phones I have ever used with microSD slot up to 2 TB and a removable battery for future proofing to boot. I have very few qualms with it. So glad this phone is ranked #9 as the most favorited on this site. It was simply overshadowed by the Samsung S7 edge and Note7. 
 
Look beyond the failed modular, rear camera, and poor sales and LG did the basics right. Fast, smooth, great camera, good price, loud, easy to hold, easy to repair, rarely gets hot, etc. Again, an overlooked phone perhaps too ahead of its time for the masses to fully grasp like the Sega Dreamcast but will accumulate a cult following over time...

That will depend on your preferences ans habits. G5 is naturally cheaper than the V20. It's also smaller, so one hand usage will be much better.
 
I never experienced a bootloop on my G5, btw. Buy one! Just put a case around it. Also protect it with a tempered glass. Scuffs and scratches almost always give heartaches to phone owners.

Go for LG as long as the battery is user-replacebale, and the screen is IPS-LCD. I admit that this is mainly my preference, but the advantage is already stated by the two other people who replied to you (especially regarding battery).
 
AMOLED screen is great, if not the best, in contrast, but it does burn in depending on how long your screen-on time is. No exceptions. I owned a Nokia C7 and a Galaxy S4. They both had burn in after just a month. I checked other people's and store's Galaxy S7 units. They have burn in. It is just a matter of time.
 
I bought a G2 in 2013. It retired only last year because it was conpletely shattered after it got hurled to a concrete floor. Otherwise, it would have been working fine even now (except the slightly shortened battery life after years of use).
 
Don't buy an hTc. The price is high compared to LG (at least between flagships). Their design is good, but not their updates. I owned the One X, and its bluetooth connection with my bluetooth headset then was terrible at best. I owned a One M9+ which wasn't updated to Marshmallow. Good thing it was stolen LOL.
 
Now, I am typing this on an unrooted LG G5. It works fine. It's even more reliable than my laptop for browsing the web (largely subjective). It's nice to be on LG territory again. Get this phone. Just put a case and tempered glass protector on it if you want it to look as good as new after 4 years. Looking forward to your choice.

This this could easily last you 3-4 years. Since batteries degrade a lot over that period of time, you could just take out, and replace the battery of the G5, since its battery is removable, where other phones have their batteries sealed in

Phones with user-replaceable batteries can always help prolong a phone's life since the most likely component to give out is the battery. 
 
If you want a Samsung or Xiaomi, get a lower end one with removable battery. That's the balance you get when wanting new features and faster performance. You sacrifice efficiency.

The Snapdragon 820 is actually a pretty powerful chip as seen as how smooth and fast the OnePlus 3, G5, and HTC 10 have shown. Samsung made it look pale in comparison to their Exynos with terrible RAM management.  
 
I am also reluctant getting an iPhone X because OLED will have burn-in and think curved displays and bezel-less are useless, uncomfortable, trendy, cosmetic gimmicks. Go with the G5. It will last and last years. I have owned all kinds of brands from Samsung, Apple, HTC, and so forth. LG is the only brand that knows what I usually want. The rest keep making the same mistakes every year to appeal to the fashionista tech crowd.

Exactly! LG thinks different. When they tried doing it last year, they got bashed for it because all these so-called tech reviewers who know nothing about tech who needs a pretty design to boost their low self-esteem. Apple and now Samsung are brainwashing people for flash over substance. 
 
I just never understood the bashing this phone got. Poor build quality? Since when is having glass rears considered better build quality? The metal on the G5 might have been painted on but even the matte iPhone 7/7 Plus is known for scuffing. Mine is silver anyway which is the best neutral color to hide smudges on matte plastic or metal. And another quality that the G5 has - IT RARELY GETS HOT! 
 
I also own a Note 3, Mi 3, Moto E2, Lumia 640, and gold LG G3 Beat. I love having both my LG's next to each other and the G5 perfectly matches with my silver MacBook. The G5 easily surpasses them all my phones. My only qualm isn't the light bleed or screen retention. It is how quite dim it is. I need to put it to 100% brightness to match my Moto at only 60%.
 
The problem with the critics and blind haters is they were only devoted pointing out the G5's flaws like the gimmicky LG Friends and modular design. They called it a flop or couldn't get over the rear design when it basically looked like the Nexus 6P. But they never pointed out what the G5 did right which were the essentials at making a great phone. 
 
- Decent battery life 
- Comfortable to hold 
- Great camera on par with S7 edge 
- Excellent IPS screen 
- Loud external speaker 
- Good audio all-around 
- Great price value  
- MicroSD slot  and removable battery for future proofing storage and usage.
 
The basics. That's what the G5 got right but all the critics lie to us like the liberal media and want SEXY toss away devices. Skip the G6. No removable battery, no thanks! When LG wanted to be different last year, they got criticized. When they want to be the same ol', same ol' like the rest of them with this G6, they will be criticized. D*mn if you do, d*mn if you don't.  
 
Think about it. The smart money is on the G5. I got mine for only $240 which I paid off entirely two days later after I got it. The S7 edge is considered the best of last year but still goes for $700 and Americans get the Snapdragon 820. The SoC isn't the problem because the G5 and OP3 flies. It is Samsung's lame skin and poor optimization on the Qualcomm's. The camera and battery life might be better on it by a little over the G5, but not $460 better. G5 is a better deal than all those Chinese makers. Mi 5, Axon 7, OnePlus 3, it beats them all... 
 
G5 = Most unique, most underrated, most misunderstood, and best all-around flagship of 2016. Ahead of its time.  But a flop because it wasn't pretty enough by fashionistas who judges designs from the rear!

So like many of you, I have discovered that the G5 screen suffers from image retention/screen burn/ghosting. I found this fix from the LG G5 xda forums thread on this issue. You simply download an app called "Blue Light Filter" from Simple Design Ltd. and set the intensity to 5% with a color temperature of 1800K. You will notice pretty much no difference in the screen and there is no impact on your battery life. copy and paste

I've pretty much had it all when it comes to cell phones. The LG G5 has been one of my absolute favorites so far! 
The battery lasts me all day, its quick, never freezes, takes good quality pictures, and durable(I have broken many phones). 
You can buy replacement batteries for it, and camera add ons. 
I live in a low service area and it picks up service quite well. 
Everyone on here complaining about certain issues could all be solved if you all took proper care of your devices. Of coarse there is the exception of getting an lemon phone. 
Shutting it off once a day, clearing apps, clearing cache in phone. Not downloading second party apps.  
Not charging your phones overnight..it exhausts your battery. 
Buying a decent , not cheap, case to protect your expensive device. 
Just like anything you own...you have to take care of it for it to last. People get so use to having their phones on them, it's like second nature to throw it in your purse, back pocket, coat pocket.  
Also, I do not update any of my phones if I can help it and they have all worked flawlessly 
software wise. When I was forced into an update, I noticed small things weren't working as great as they once were. Battery life decreased, phone starting lagging. etc 
The only con is the protruded camera. Not sure why phones are going in this direction but they are much easier to smash. 
This is my opinion. Of coarse others might disagree. It is what it is.

Ran into a battery drain issue after upgrading to Nougat.  If you are using smart settings (location auto-setting) and your mobile data is off, the GPS will not be able to locate your position and your phone will become hot (processor is continuously working attempting to fulfill the auto smart settings) and your battering will drain in approx 2.5 hours. Clearly there is an issue with the Nougat build.  Recommend not using this.  Also, turn off WiFi scanning. Even if your Wifi is turned off, the scan function will continue and will add to your battery drain.
 
Otherwise, great phone.

It is not screen burn. LCD do not have screen burn but rather Amoled. What you mean is Image retention and its a major issue with LCD displays but it temporary. It should go off once your phone is not in use say over night. You can also download any "Blue Light Filter" app off google play. It will prevent this Image Retention.

I have this phone for about 6 months and I'm impressed by LG. Cameras are excellent (back cameras have very good picture quality, and the front camera too, it's wide and it takes great sefies), the speaker gets very loud and it has great sound quality. Snapdragon 820 with 4GB RAM is lightning fast and everything is super smooth. Battery is average, but it's not bad. You can get  around 5 hours of extreme usage (for example playing heavy games on LTE), but with the lighter use you can get full day without problem. It supports fast charging, and it's working very well(full charge in less than an hour). Screen is very vibrant and produces vivid colors, but it has little problem with burn-ins, and is very hard to notice, but it's there. Fingerprint sensor is working excellent, in less than a second. If anyone want a flagship phone with excellent specs for a little less money than the other competition(price is below 400$), than I can definitely recommend this phone. :)

I am mainly an iPhone user but I read somewhere that if you are in the market for a second phone then get something that is not like the main one you already have & I got the G5 to see if the whole Android experience was better since I had the HTC M8 & for the most part, I am happy with it, not happy enough to make it my 'daily driver' but from an over all point of view I am happy at how Android has progressed & I can see it getting better.
 
My only gripe with getting a LG handset is that the UI is an overlay of Android so this causes minor glitches & lags. If I want to put a custom launcher on it such as Nova (paid) or Aviate (these were my favourite customer launchers when using my M8) then you have a 3 way battle as to what skin you want to use with the one that you select often coming out as the winner but with more minor issues.
 
For instance, today I took a phone call & the answer screen looked like it was the Android Jellybean screen with the answer icon in the centre & the little dots coming away from it asking me to swipe & not the LG one that I have always seen since I have had it my G5.
 
In terms of build, I like it, dont like where the battery slides in & leaves you with a gap & a sharp edge though! Sure it would of been easier for LG to make the phone out of the same slab & then cut off what was needed for the battery or 'Friends' part. Using the LG case has solved this for me.
 
Do I think that I will ever stop using my iPhone & go to an Android full time? Maybe, if the V20 came to the UK or the Mi Mix then I would think about it for sure!

(Also posted on the Lg G5 SE page comments.) 
Warning: I'm a consumer rights activist, and the 'SE' model of this phone has been slipped into the stores here in the UK with very little if any publicity. (I'm in the biz, so know.) My carrier (EE) and Carphone Warehouse try to sell you the G5 SE when you ask for a pure G5, yet the cash price in store is only £20 less and the contracts similar.
 
The lower power processor is a MAJOR issue. We all know that for smooth operation, gaming and decent smooth video, a good CPU is paramount.
 
When I give advice to friend and family, I say, you want a phone that is: Fast, has a daylight readable display and all day battery. I cannot speak for the 2nd two items, but the SE will not be as fast as the 5G. A compromise has been made to help LG move stock of the original G5, but save them money, so they have switched CPUs.
 
There is a difference between a genuine budget model of a phone and one that is only slightly tweaked so consumers don't realise. The SE lettering on the box is very small.
 
I think this very dishonest of LG and the carriers and today, I told EE and Carphone Warehouse to their faces and via their call centres that they need to stop doing this.
 
I'm going to order a pure G5 now as it's a great phone (had one before), the only downside being battery life and in my case before, screen was dull outside, but I think it was a one off.
 
Hope this advice is helpful! I will post this on the G5 page too.

LG G5 vs Sony Xperia X

LG G5 - have one and love it.
 
For pics, it depends. The Zenfone 3 has phase detect autofocus in addition which is good for focusing on subjects that are moving (towards or away from you). Stability is a bit better to with it's OIS being 4-axis where the G5 is 3-axis. However, the lens of the G5 is a bit brighter/faster because of the wider aperture (f/1.8 vs f/2), i.e. better low-light, but more importantly it has a second rear camera with an ultra-wide 135-degree lens. I really like using this, it's great for landscape obviously but also when you're in a really small or crowded place and have no room to walk further away to capture your subject completely. 
 
For gaming, G5 is better for sure - faster/better CPU and GPU plus higher resolution screen.

LG G5 NEW Tip......  
I never saw this trick in any review or video online. Very Useful:
 
Triple click (tap..tap..tap) quickly on your onscreen home button. It will turn the coloured screen to black and white (Greyscale) thus saving a lot of battery when required. No more going into settings..finding greyscale & turning it on and then off-for those who care to use it. Triple tap again to turn colour back on. 
 
It is so convenient that I have started to use it in various long office meetings (when phone on silent) even when I have full/ good battery. Improves my battery efficiency by almost 30%. Earlier I was getting 1.5 days battery..now can extend to 2 full days using this trick.

I chose the G5.

I created an account here just to share my experience using LG G5. Amazing!!! Previously I was using Sony Xperia Z1, good set, but it took no Android updates after Android 5, the battery was poor and after two years of use it really sucked. Went to buy Samsung Note 7, not yet launched but my Xperia was giving me utter trouble. Thought why not try LG G4 beacause G5 has reduced the screen size! Anyway, finally bought LG G5.  
1. Only 2800 MaH battery, thought will drain out supporting 1440x2560 pixels with 554 ppi. I was utterly wrong. Extremely good battery, far better than Sony. Lasted almost throughout the day till 9 pm. Very good power management from LG. Kudos. 
2. Very fast finger sensor. 
3. Camera is awesome! With dual camera and the super wide angle image and the image quality even in low light conditions, it is definitely better than existing Samsung S7 edge and way better than my Xperia Z1. 
4. The sound quality without head phones is pretty loud and with the earphones and surround sound mode, it is definitely better than my Z1. I saw a video in you tube that LG friends have HiFi plus which boosts the sound to 32 bit but I think is not currently launched in India. 
5. The processor is damn fast and makes multi tasking a breezer! 
Hope to use the LG friends accessories soon to get the full 360 degree amusement form LG G5.

After reading so many bad comments about this phone (mostly from people who don't own it...) I have decided to purchase this phone, now at around 408 USD (1500 AED here in Dubai). The price is actually ok for the specs of this phone, got the H860 variant Titan. For that price you won't get the freebies but thats fine with me. I did not get this phone with regards to its modular features...actually im not interested at all. I just got because of the removable battery. Very economical option in case your battery dies, you just get a new one and pop it in, whereas if it were a galaxy s7 or s7 edge, a dead battery would mean a quick trip to the repair shop and surely it would not be cheap. I don't have any issues with this phone, performance wise it delivers as a flagship. battery life can last me through a day, with a mixed use of social media, bluetooth streaming, majority use of internet is through mobile data. At the end of my day which is around 10pm, i still have about 30-40 percent battery life. I dont have issues with build quality, got mine perfect. No heating issues also, gets a little warm though if i play mortal kombat x for an hour :). I can safely recommend this phone to anyone wants to try an LG.

I have the G5 since one month now, and i must say i totally agree with your review. It's the most comprehensive realistic review.

Quick review after a week: 
(Have put G5 in a tough grippy £10 case with a kickstand, now not as slippery so harder to drop!)
 
Very fast, no lag 
Very good auto focus on camera 
Wide angle mode on camera is excellent although you get fish eye effect at edges, hopefully LG or Adobe release a fix? 
Screen offers realistic colours but is not as bright outdoors as my previous phones (Note 4, Moto X 2nd gen etc) 
So so battery life so I keep charger in bag. 
USB-C is great as is fast charging. 
Camera photos are sharp but look like those from a Sony camera, a bit mushy on closeup. Prefer Samsung images TBH! 
Manual camera controls very flexible. 
Ability to add controls (such as notifications panel toggle) to main nav strip is v useful. Unique to LG. 
Fingerprint login is great. 
Miss rear volume controls of my G3 but I guess that is to avoid accidental activation fingerprint login? (Only requires a touch) 
FM Radio a nice bonus, didnt know G5 had one! 
Not tried 4K video yet. 
Call quality much improved since LG software update. 
Signal reception way better than my last few phones. For a metal phone, v clever. 
No crashes etc yet. 
Have inserted a 64GB microSD card for extra memory if travelling away from connectivity for cloud upload of photos etc. 
Not a very pretty phone and I doubt I will use Friends modules. Case it if you don't like design, like I have. 
Miss wireless charging, had a wireless back on Note 4, and had a G3 once too. 
Am waiting for Note 7, but if I can work out how to improve camera images may keep G5. 
G5 is starting to fall to £400 here in UK (Vodafone & online) so is now very good value for such a well specified 32GB device!
 
Hope that is useful.

I have taken more than good time and have gone through every possible you tube video review and any other good article about any possible good phone that could be my next flagship. This included crazy follow up for months and months on Galaxy S7, Huawei P9, Nexus 6P, LG G5, HTC 10, One Plus 3, Xiomi Mi5 and even ZTE Axon 7. I actually bought the G5 finally only on 8 July once on 7 July the ZTE Axon camera review came out and I found the camera on it was crap. Anyways, With my analysis I could conclude the below things- 
1) All phones have goods & bads but only the Galaxy S7 & LG G5 are the most complete phones. It comes down to what the actual preferences for a particular person are- tradeoffs are to be made in both phones.  
2) Samsung  spent big time on its marketing campaign (as always) and LG probably spent nothing (as always)- Result- Samsung Kicked LGs butt and now S7 is outselling G5 by the tons (not necessarily because it is better) I could find most reviews biased towards the Galaxy S7 all over the internet. Many a times I almost thought many-many (ahmm..ahmm) were paid to promote the S7 and highly denigrate the G5 to kill competition in the bud. 
3) Galaxy S7 is definitely there with better display (Amoled), better themes, really neat and handy tricks and the likes. However all the fuss about design and premium is bullshit- For me Glass is definitely NO PREMIUM. I am yet to come across a person (and there S7 has had a bumper sale here) who does not have a case on his Galaxy S7- there goes the premium design inside a INR 300 ($5) case. The front & back glasses are so-so easy to break if they fall down- Hence, I decided to give it a skip- so much money not worth the risk. My G5 also goes in a case, so no big deal here. Personally I found the dual camera setup enticing, meaning more people noticing my phone. 
3) Taking a sum of all positive negative and blind voting contest (most important as here paid things are less likely to work)- G5 definitely has the better camera- even in low light (agreed S7 has faster autofocus) and many-many other diverse conditions. But S7 has taken all the possible accolades for various worthy & sometimes unworthy reasons. The gimmick of scaling down to 12 MP (though enough-but not good) was hyped too much everywhere. I bet they could give 16 MP outright, but they will probably be saving it for Galaxy S8 with dual pixel bluff etc etc. for next year. I think LG did win here on the primary camera alone and that the wide angle camera was also there was just awesome. Made my choice very simple.  Today, when I compare photos shot with my friends S7 edge & my G5 all agree that the G5 photos look much better when viewed on a proper 14-16 inch monitor. Secret- In many reviews, what the reviewers dont tell is that for comparison purposes, the G5 16 MP pics are scaled down to 12 MP for comparing like to like pics with S7 which is unfair-even more so when the reader is not told of the same- So of-course the G5 pics are made to look less than what they originally are. 
4) Not helping themselves much, LG further dug their own grave by launching it at around INR 53K in such a HUGE market as India (Just too expensive for the good and bad that G5 offered) when the S7 was selling at INR 49K. Now that they have realised their mistake and normalised the rates by the various freebies & discounts (which I got- listed in earlier comments)- this phone has become a really good buy. I was anticipating such a scenario and grabbed as soon as it came. 
Anyways, I still am thank full to all reviewers for they made my understanding of one and all devices so detailed that I could take an educated and informed decision on what is good for me rather than being told what should be good for me.

I have had the LG G3, and the G4.  Before that i was an HTC only boy.  I got the lg G5 on pre-order from sprint and received it on March 31st.  I do not like that they made the screen smaller, even though its only a little bit i wish they would have kept the screen at 5.5 but i think the reason behind this is because of the new V line from LG.  Basically i think the v10 is the lg G4 pro version.  My carrier is the only one that does not carry the V10 because i probably would have gotten that phone instead but that phone does have a crappy processor and video GPU just like the G4 does but they did that because the snapdragon 810 had so many problems so they went with the 808.  Second, i don't get why people are saying the screen is so dim, if you look at the brightness specifications, its twice as bright as the G4 and G3.  Now what i will say is the "auto" function on the screen brightness doesn't work exactly right and sometimes i will go into the settings and turn the auto function off and back on and that fixes it all the time.  i have no problem seeing the screen at all in full sunlight.  i absolutely love that they kept the removeable battery, so i also don't understand why people were bitching about the smaller battery, they even had a promo that if u bought the phone at a certain time they would send u a free battery and charging cradle.  i used that promo and got my extra battery and cradle and love it.  I also purchased an extra non-oem battery from amazon for $16 bucks.  So now i have three batteries, if it gets close to dying, i simply turn the phone off and swap the batteries.  I NEVER charge the phone (but i did when i first got it and it charges very fast, about an hour and 15 minutes gets a full charge)  Now more about the display, i prefer IPS displays over samsungs amolded.  First, the amolded displays look fake and over saturated.  also the pixels die out over time.  plus the samsungs are usually quite a bit more then the LG devices.  Now that wasn't quite the case this time.  i believe it was still about 100$ cheaper then the regular s7 and 200$ cheaper then the s7 edge.  the g4 was alot cheaper then the samsung s6 and s6 edge but since they have the same processors and ram and gpu i guess they decided to charge more.  Changing the batteries was a pain at first with the weird design but after a few weeks i can change them within a few seconds.  i've read many professional reviews of the g5 and they all say it is by far the fastest as any of the new devices this year.  it has also won awards for the best camera out of all of them too.  i think the main 16mp shooter is the same from the lg g4.  there is an extra 8mp wide angle lens but i am not much on taking pictures, i played with it a little and it seems ok.  I think it also has the same 8mp front shooter as the g4.  The speaker is on the bottom now instead of the back and it seems pretty good, a little better then on the g4's back facing speaker.  overall i really like this phone.  it is extremely fast and does all the things all the other phones do.  i really like that it still comes with a removeable battery as i hate charging my phone even if it does charge really fast.  i had six extra batteries for my g4.  the call quality and reception are great (i am on sprint which is the worst of all the US carriers but it works great, i am usually home on my wifi anyway but i don't use wifi for calling.  I did switch from Tmobile and i got much better service with them but sprint isn't that bad and they are working on improving.  I don't use the second screen option because i have a smart watch but from what i read from reviews its the best out of any phone but still sucks.  I give this phone an 8 out of 10.  Some places even have this phone buy one get one free or buy one get one 50% off.  just shop around.

-Lack of bloatware.

-Messaging system can hold 40,000+ messages without freezing or lagging to much. 
-Fast Charge 3.0 
-Swappable battery.

Cons:

-App drawer is missing (I don't mind it) 
-Having trouble syncing 1300+ phone contacts from google sometimes. Hit or miss. 
-Annoying drawer system to eject the Micro SD card/Sim card. Requires a needle. Don't lose the needle.

There is a dual-SIM version, the H860N (Hong Kong).  Alas contrary to GSM Arena's specs, the H860N is a shared second slot, either it is a second SIM OR a SD card.  Rather major bummer there.  If you could use the second SIM at the same time as a SD card, the low memory of the G5 wouldn't be so bad, but with it being shared it is a dealbreaker.
 
Many are wanting the SD card standards to change to having the default filesystem be UDF instead of vfat, but so far they've been opting for vfat.  Hopefully this will change, but it hasn't yet.  I don't know whether the G5 supports UDF formatted SD cards.

Has LG got it right with their new LG G5 design? I thinks so.  
After much talk about the new modular design of the G5, I can say for myself as a NEW OWNER, that LG have got it right.
 
I'm off contract and I purchased a G5 Titan sim free. at £529 that came with free LG B&O H3 in-ear headphones.
 
The LG G5 is one phone that can change into many with the add-ons like LG Hi-Fi Plus with B&O PLAY and LG CAM - Plus, will make the phone stand out even more.
 
Positives with the new G5 are? 
That this phone will allow you to grow and expand not just with the add-ons from LG Friends Family - which are great but a little expensive. But also with the ability to expand the phones memory from 32BG up to 200 GB with the use of the microSD card slot. Plus you also have the ability to swap-out the phone's battery, if needed. With a spare battery you can always make sure that your have power when needed. Just these two abilities on there own make the phone worth having. Plus the G5's power and design make this a flagship mobile phone worth having and I think well above the Samsung Galaxy S7!
 
Negatives of the G5 are? 
Well there aren't many, but over the last 48 hours I've been putting my new G5 through the test. I've changed and played around with most of the phones settings and the G5 hasn't fallen over once. However, what I have noticed is the the fingerprint sensor on my G5 stops working if the phone is either in long periods of standby or when the phone is switched off and then back on. 
Yes the G5 fingerprint sensor will not operate first time when the phone is turned on. This is a design security feature. But I have also found that my G5 fingerprint sensor has to be reset by deleting the existing fingerprints and re add them, otherwise they will not work. Then the sensor works for the rest of the day. This may be sorted out with an update for the G5. 
The other issue be it a small one is the modular design of the G5. The 2 parts of the phone that separate don't provide a smooth finish when locked back with each other. On my G5 I have one side of the phone where it comes apart higher than the other side. It's not much but you just feel it every time I hold the phone in my hand, it's not a all smooth finish. Thoughts on this are - If you design a phone that has a feature that comes apart make sure that they totally go back together with a all smooth finish, otherwise it makes the phone feel cheap and not a flagship that it is.
 
I rate this 4.5 out of 5 - It's the fingerprint sensor and the not all smooth finish that just let's it down for me.

I like much of what is expected in the LG G5, there are some items in the current reports I'm concerned about or outright dislike.
 
The screen and battery aren't tiny, but they're still both on the smaller side.  I'll simply have to live with these, but still.
 
Sure, metal case may be premium, but that nearly always gets covered.  I'd like to see a company sell a phone without a back cover.  Offer a back cover for an extra charge, or simply let the protective back cover be the only back cover.  Having the entire back cover be removable would more easily allow for larger expansion batteries.
 
They've got preliminary specifications for processor and graphics unit.  Seems only the H850 is getting the Snapdragon 820.  While the H840 is getting an older generation, but more cores.  More cores can help, but often the newer generation wins.
 
I'm glad though that it appears all versions will feature full IrDA.  Even though codes for existing remotes generally become well known, being able to simply copy a new remote can often be handier.  Plus this means you get bidirectional communication with other IR devices instead of merely being able to emulate remote controls.  This is assuming they follow the path of their earlier devices though.  I'm also glad for *proper* dual-SIM, instead of going for style and consuming the micro-SD slot for a second SIM.

Hi, the reason the phone says it supports up to 200 GB microSD cards is because that is currently the biggest microSD card available for purchase. The phones has been designed to accept up to 2 TB microSD but the actual peripheral has not caught up to the maximum capacity yet. It is like placing an 8 GB card in a Note 3's 64 GB slot, the slot allows for higher capacities but the card doesn't meet that maximum amount. I hope this clears it up somewhat.

Hi, I am currently an LG G3 user and had that phone for a year and a half - it's the best phone i ever had; the messeges app seems to be only one that lags a little when opening but after optimizing my phone (switching off unnecessary settings and uninstalling unneeded apps) it runs very smoothly. The level of customization on my LG is astonishing - from little things like keyboard design and heigh adjustment to re-sizing apps and their icon picture on the homescreen, etc....basically i love my LG G3 (despite it having mediocre battery life)...
 
This being said, my next phone will be the S7 Edge - i am sorry to say! That phone is a beast. You say that the G5 has 3.0 charging and it will be quicker, but i don't care about that - because i will always have an hour and half to spare before going to bed when i leave my phone on charge. I would be surprised if the G5 will score 60-65 hours here on gsm battery test. The S7 Edge scored 98 hours!! and 20h on video playback alone! That is amazing and something a phone over £500 deserves to have.
 
I will miss my LG and its detailed meticulous levels of customization, but i can't say no to S7 Edge's design, camera and battery. I am thoroughly disappointed by LG this year. Whilst innovative as always (the modular design is arguably revolutionary), they seemed to have forgotten that it's a smartphone in the first place - 2800 mAh on a phone that is optimized worse than Samsung just doesn't cut it for me...
 
That's just me. Everybody is different; but i do think LG have shot themselves in the foot this year...

Mostly true, but you forget something in your equation. The SD820 is supposed to up its game when it comes to energy efficiency and the always-on notification screen could also have positive impact. If I recall it correctly, newer Androids save energy by postponing many background tasks when the device is in sleep mode, processing them all once you wake the device up. So if you just check the notifications and put the device back to sleep few times a day, all those amassed background tasks can burn up a lot of juice for only a marginal benefit to you. If implemented correctly, this feature could save considerable amount of power for moments when you really need it. So the smaller battery is not necessarily a hindrance. It will not be something to write home about, but if LG doesn't screw up, it could still hold its own under normal daily regime.

The more I read about the G5, the more I want it over the S7 edge. LG is really thinking for the next decade. You can only do so much with a slab design. The biggest G5 complaints I hear are... 
 
- FUGLY design. I think it is ok. When the Nexus 6P came out, not many people complained on the looks. What LG proved is you can have a metal design and still have a removable battery like the old HTC days. I think the slide-out modular design is a fantastic concept that is probably a few years ahead of its time. Some thought the fingerprint scanner was a gimmick before becoming a mainstay. Apple even copied the always-on Siri taking cues from the og Moto X.
 
- 2800 mAh battery. This might not be remedied except through the fast charging (0-83% in 30 minutes) and being swappable for something bigger. 
 
Too many people complaining on the superficial when the real beauty with the G5 is within.. and it slides out too. I have went back and forth with the pluses and minuses of removable battery which other OEM's have gone away because of the metal or glass designs. LG just showed us how to have the best of both worlds while opening up potential with LG Friends with the other. By the 2020's decade, how we all use our smartphone will change with our daily habits. 
 
LG G5 might be the most innovative smartphone since the original iPhone. But it is the LG hardware and not Apple software like what iOS brought to the table. The S6/S7 edge is more "gimmick" than the modular design of the G5. I hope more OEM's actually copy this modular design to revive removable batteries again. Because we all know battery is the first one to go broke after so many charges.

When we are talking about CPU, then only the single core performance is what matters. Because most Android programs and games are single threaded (for example the most CPU intensive programs are the emulators (DosBox, PPSSPP, ...), they use mainly 1 core only). 
Multicore benchmarks are brainwashing gimmicks for the ignorants. In real world, you will NEVER use all cores at 100%, so you will never experience the benefit of 8 cores.
 
And when we are talking about GPU, then only the on-screen benchmark is what matters. Because only that measures the real world performance. 
The idiot phone manufacturers and brainwashed consumers, article authors think phones need QHD screen resolution. But in fact, it's pointless for phones. 720p is perfectly enough for phones. (Don't forget that Samsung phones have Amoled display. They have PenTile subpixes which makes it pixelated, so they need higher resolution to hide the pixelation. It's another reason along with burn-in problems, why IPS LCD is better.)
